content.question:
For which of the following functions is the chain rule an appropriate method to find the derivative with respect to <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ?
<math alttext="y equals, the cosine of, open parenthesis, the square root of x, end root, plus 1, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msqrt><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msqrt><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="y equals, 2 to the x power, times sine x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msup><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="y equals, the fraction with numerator 20, and denominator 40 times x squared, minus 1, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>40</mn><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>

unit.text: 3: Differentiation: Composite, Implicit, and Inverse Functions

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the classification of a given expression (e.g., Use the chain rule to find the derivative of a composite function).
